Migration models with DemoTools

José Manuel Aburto, Ilya Kashnitsky, Monica Alexander, Jorge Cimentada, Tim Riffe

2020-06-27

Source: vignettes/migration_with_demotools.Rmd
migration_with_demotools.Rmd

How to use DemoTools to model migration

Why modeling migration

Migrations happens with multiple transitions over the life course such as entry to education, new job or retirement (Preston, Heuveline, and Guillot 2000). These transitions happen more frequently at some ages and come in parallel often with migration. Adult migration usually peaks at youn adult ages. Around age at retirement there is a second peak. Because of these regularities it is, therefore, possible to model migration by age, which is very important for policy makers and for demographers in estimating population dynamics.

The Rogers and Castro model

Rogers and Castro (1981) developed a mathematical model of migration with 11 parameter. Seven of these parameters explain the shape of migration by age, while the rest of parameters represent the intensity of migration. The original formula for the migration rate at age \(x\) is:

\[\begin{equation*} m(x)= a_1 \exp{[ \alpha_1 x ]} + a_2 \exp{[ -\alpha_2 (x - \mu_2) - \exp{ [ -\lambda_2(x - \mu_2) ]} ]}+ a_3 \exp{[ - \alpha_3(x-\mu_3) - \exp{[-\lambda_3 (x-\mu_3)]} ]} + c \end{equation*}\]

@ Monica: some interpretation of the coefficients?

Example with DemoTools

An example, flexibility of parameters in R, and interpretation of results @ Monica: could you help with this section?

References

Preston, Samuel, Patrick Heuveline, and Michel Guillot. 2000. Demography: Measuring and Modeling Population Processes. Wiley-Blackwell.

Rogers, Andrei, and Luis J Castro. 1981. “Model Migration Schedules.” IIASA Working Papers.
